questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Live and subcutaneous: While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C. Live and intramuscular: Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D. Killed and subcutaneous: Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Article 21 

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the Right to Life and personal liberty to all its citizens. This article is pivotal as it ensures that no person is deprived of their life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law. This right is comprehensive, covering a range of aspects that ensure not just mere survival but a life with dignity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Article 11: Defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

 

Option C. Article 23: Defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

 

Option D. Article 25: Defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion. While it pertains to personal liberties, it specifically addresses religious freedoms and not the general Right to Life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is critical as it enshrines the Right to Life and personal liberty, ensuring that every individual's life and personal freedoms are protected under the law.

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome: This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.

 

Option C. Bell's Palsy: While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome: This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text: Which of the following tumors arises from the olfactory nasal mucosa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Esthesioneuroblastoma

 

Explanation:


Esthesioneuroblastoma, also called olfactory neuroblastoma, specifically arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity. It is also known as olfactory placode tumor, highlighting its origin from the specialized olfactory mucosa. This tumor typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, and can invade surrounding structures including the orbit and intracranial cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal Glioma: This is a congenital lesion that represents entrapped neural tissue during embryonic development. It doesn't arise from the olfactory mucosa but is a developmental anomaly. Nasal gliomas are typically seen in infants and children and may be extranasal (60%), intranasal (30%) or both (10%).

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: This tumor arises from the glands of the mucous membrane or minor salivary glands, rather than from the olfactory epithelium. It typically involves the upper part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity but is not derived from olfactory tissue.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This tumor originates from the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx, not from the olfactory mucosa in the nasal cavity. It arises from a completely different anatomical site.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Esthesioneuroblastoma is a distinctive neoplasm that uniquely originates from the specialized olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal cavity, making it the only true tumor of olfactory mucosal origin among the options provided.

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: Constituents of nasal septum include all except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perpendicular plate of palatine

 

Explanation: 

 

The nasal septum is composed of both bony and cartilaginous components. The main constituents include the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone superiorly, the vomer posteroinferiorly, the quadrangular cartilage anteriorly, and the maxillary crest inferiorly. The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone is not a constituent of the nasal septum.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vomer: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The vomer is a thin, flat bone that forms the posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum. It articulates with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid superiorly and the maxillary crest inferiorly.

 

Option C. Quadrangular cartilage: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The quadrangular cartilage (septal cartilage) forms the major anterior portion of the nasal septum. It is attached to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid posterosuperiorly and to the vomer posteroinferiorly.

 

Option D. Maxillary crest: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The maxillary crest forms a ridge along the nasal floor that supports the inferior edge of the nasal septum. It is formed by the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The nasal septum consists of the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone, vomer, quadrangular cartilage, and maxillary crest, but does not include the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.
